clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy Study of Hydroxychloroquine to Treat High-risk Coronary Artery Disease.
clinical_study.official_title: Hydroxychloroquine Assessment of Management Study in Coronary Artery Disease After Angiography.

lead_sponsor.agency: First Affiliated Hospital Xi'an Jiaotong University

clinical_study.source: First Affiliated Hospital Xi'an Jiaotong University

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether treated with hydroxychloroquine could improve therapeutic effect for patients with high-risk coronary artery disease.

detailed_description.textblock: This double blind, placebo, randomized controlled cross-over trial is going to assess if hydroxychloroquine could improve the high sensitivity C-reaction protein, blood lipid, blood glucose and blood pressure, also whether hydroxychloroquine could affect the secretion of inflammatory cytokines and the M1/M2 phenotype polarization of macrophages in patients with high-risk coronary artery disease.

intervention.description: Subjects are treated with oral hydroxychloroquine sulfate tablets 200mg twice daily for 16 weeks. After that, there is a 23-week washout period. criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients have the symptom of angina and ST-T change, as well as one coronary artery stenosis≥50% at least confirmed by coronary angiography or CT angiography at the age of 18-75 years old.
- High sensitivity C-reactive protein >3mg/L, GRACE risk score≥90 .
- On guideline-based secondary prevention of coronary heart disease medications≥3 months.
- No use of steroids, antibiotics, immunosuppressors a week before treatment.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Retinal disease.
- Chronic hepatopathy.
- Renal dysfunction (creatinine>175mmol/L).
- Moderately severe anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukocytopenia.
- Other contraindications for hydroxychloroquine.
- Active hemorrhage.
- Cancer or life expectancy< a year.
- New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class≥class III, Percutaneous Coronary Intervention or Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting in plan.
- Pregnancy and lactation.
